text:
When defining variables in a begin/end block like:
```begin
  x = 1
  y = 2
end```
the value displayed is just `2`.  But if they are defined like:
```y = begin
  x = 1
  2
end```
then the value is displayed as `y = 2`.  Is there a general preference for one way vs the other?  I guess it depends on what the author wants to convey so maybe it's too context sensitive for a general preference, but I'd be curious to hear what others think.

text:
i like to do something like
```begin
  x = 1
  y =2
end; md"Setup  variables x,y "```
that way when i hide the code i can still find it later on based on the markdown.

text: Wow, neat!  I hadn't realized that semicolon separated "parts" would prevent "multiple expressions in one cell" errors.  I'll add that to my bag of tricks.  Thanks!

elements.text: Wow, neat!  I hadn't realized that semicolon separated "parts" would prevent "multiple expressions in one cell" errors.  I'll add that to my bag of tricks.  Thanks!

text: you can also put the markdown as the last line in the `begin...end` block.

text:
Try what semantically makes sense
```y = begin
  x = 1
  2
end```
doesn’t make sense to me, y isn’t `x = 1` , so what is that doing there!!
I like cells, so I just put it in multiple cells, so I get `x = 1` and `y = 2` :grin:
